item.title: Monopoly GO: Captain’s Quest Rewards and Milestones
item.description:
Continuing the theme of finding lost riches underwater, Scopely has come out with an all-new solo event for Monopoly GO , called Captain’s Quest. This two-day event coincides with the final two days of the ongoing Sunken Treasures digging minigame , giving you one last chance to stockpile hammer tokens.

The Captain’s Quest solo event will run from May 25 to May 27 and offers tons of exciting rewards. By strategically participating in the Captain’s Quest event, you can secure a significant amount of dice rolls, cash, and hammers to maximize your gains. Read on to learn how to make the most of Monopoly GO ’ s Captain’s Quest event.

Related
Monopoly GO: How To Get Free Hammers For Sunken Treasures

Hammer Tokens are needed to dig out hidden objects in Monopoly GO’s Sunken Treasures minigame. Here’s how to get more of them.

Captain’s Quest Rewards and Milestones

The Captain’s Quest solo event is spread over 50 unique milestones, where each one unlocks a bigger and better prize. By completing all 50 milestones, you can win a total of 13,845 dice rolls , 235 hammer tokens, eight sticker packs, and much more. Check out the table below for a complete list of all the rewards and milestones in Monopoly GO ’s Captain’s Quest event.

How To Get Points in Captain’s Quest

To score points in the Captain’s Quest, you have to land on the designated pickup tiles scattered across the board. These tiles feature a unique icon that perfectly fits the event’s theme. Each landing nets you two points.

You can earn more points and speed up your progress by strategically rolling with a higher dice multiplier (like x100) when you have a clear path to a pickup tile.

item.title: The Planet Crafter: How to Build a Fusion Reactor
item.description:
As you terraform the world of The Planet Crafter , you need to build bigger and stronger power systems to keep all your machines and displays running. You start out with renewable sources like wind and solar panels, but you can eventually build nuclear power plants that produce immense amounts of energy.

The ultimate power source in The Planet Crafter is the fusion reactor, which you unlock when you reach 750 micro-Kelvin. However, the reactor doesn't call for uranium like the nuclear reactors do. So how can you get what you need?

Related
The Planet Crafter: Best Starting Locations

Just starting off in The Planet Crafter? These locations are some of the best for early-game. Here's what their pros and cons are as well.

Fusion Reactor Basics

The basic unit of Heat in The Planet Crafter is pico-Kelvin, and 750 micro-Kelvin is equal to 750 million pico-Kelvin. You should expect to reach the Trees or Insects terraformation stage by the time you unlock the fusion reactor. However, you may unlock the reactor sooner if you focus on building heaters and heat-multiplying rockets.

Each fusion reactor costs five pulsar quartz and four super alloy . A single fusion reactor generates 1,485 kW, which is over four times as much energy as the nuclear reactor T2. The materials you need for a fusion reactor are almost completely different from the materials the T2 reactor demands, so there's no real point to dismantling them. 300 kW is still significant, and since the materials the fusion reactor needs are rare, it makes sense to keep the T2 reactors around as backup.

One other way you can make the most of each fusion reactor is to build machine optimizers nearby and stock them with energy multiplier fuses. You can buy them from the space trader for 6,000 Terra Tokens , and you can also find them in safes in procedural ruins.

Related
How to Find Every Underground Bunker in Planet Crafter

There are six total bunkers underneath the dangerous surface of the planet in The Planet Crafter, each with loot and lore inside of them.

Where to Get Super Alloy and Pulsar Quartz

You need super alloy in a variety of machine recipes, especially by the time you unlock the fusion reactor. However, you need a lot of it for each reactor. More importantly, you also need a special mineral called pulsar quartz, and the fusion reactor may be the first recipe you unlock that requires it. As such, you'll need to secure a regular source of both materials if you want to build as many as you'll need to power the late-game machines.

Super Alloy

Super alloy is the easier material to get. There are a few places you can find them, one place you can mine them, and the recipe is easy enough to unlock.

  • Check the upper ledges of the Labyrinth Caverns for super alloy.
  • Inspect the ground below the Sand Falls to find a few nuggets.
  • There's a cave full of super alloy in the cliff wall by the Dune Desert and the Highlands. You can extract an unlimited supply of super alloy from this cave with an ore extractor T2 or T3 .
  • One of the meteor shower events drops dozens of super alloy nuggets. However, you'll need to be careful since the meteors land in rapid succession and the super alloy despawns faster than any other meteor product. This means you'll need to dodge meteors if you want to fill your inventory.
  • Super alloy shows up often in crates once you reach the green stages of terraformation.
  • If you deconstruct a golden crate, you get one super alloy and one aluminum.
  • Super alloy is one of the recipes that comes for free with the advanced craft station. The station unlocks once you reach the first terraformation milestone of 175 kTi. You need one of each basic mineral to build it:
    • Iron
    • Cobalt
    • Magnesium
    • Silicon
    • Titanium
    • Aluminum

Pulsar Quartz

The first time you collect a piece of pulsar quartz , you get the achievement "The Pink Rare Ore." You can eventually unlock a recipe that lets you craft it in the biolab, but until then you'll need to hunt down the locations on the map that hold it. The ore extractor can't generate pulsar quartz (or any kind of quartz), so you're stuck with what's on the map until you can unlock the recipe or start visiting procedural wrecks.

  • Scattered throughout the Meteor Field.
  • A few quartz pieces are on top of the large Waterfall.
  • Inside the cave connecting the Crater and the Arches biomes.
  • Inside the cave in one of the sinkholes south of the Gate Desert.
  • The Rainbow Caves include one or two caves of each type of quartz , including pulsar quartz.
  • During the late terraformation stages, a large purple meteor will sometimes crash down and drop around six to eight pulsar quartz.
  • Pulsar quartz shows up in chests you open after reaching the Trees stage.
  • Pulsar quartz is a relatively common find in procedural wrecks .
  • The recipe for pulsar quartz unlocks after you reach 175 GTi. You need several rare materials to make it:
    • Iridium
    • Uranium
    • Osmium
    • Zeolite
    • Methane cartridge

item.title: Disney Dreamlight Valley: Dreamlight Parks Fest Decorate Walkthrough
item.description:
Disney Dreamlight Valley 's Dreamlight Parks Fest is bursting with things to do, from completing Daily and Weekly quests to making cupcakes, and more. One such Weekly Quest is called 'Dreamlight Parks Fest: Decorate,' and is given by Scrooge McDuck. It's a challenging and time-consuming quest with so many ingredients to gather, so you might first wonder how to complete it and, ultimately, what are some of the fastest ways of getting everything you need.

Although it takes time to gather all the necessary ingredients for Scrooge's Decorate quest, it's worth the effort for the reward you get on completion, plus the fun Valley decorations you can place along the way.

Related
Disney Dreamlight Valley: All Popcorn Buckets (& How To Get Them)

Disney Dreamlight Valley's Dreamlight Park Fest enables players to create themed Popcorn Buckets. Here's what is needed to craft them.

How To Start Dreamlight Parks Fest: Decorate

The Dreamlight Parks Fest: Decorate Quest is only available during the Dreamlight Parks Fest event. It's also a Weekly Quest given out by Scrooge McDuck, so you will need to talk to Scrooge to activate and begin it. Scrooge wants to decorate the Valley with some festival-themed decorations. To do so, you first need to gather all the necessary ingredients to craft them.

Gather The Materials

For the first part of the Decorate Quest, Scrooge gives you a list of crafting ingredients to gather as pictured above. Some of these are easier and quicker than others to get hold of. It's also best to get as many of these ingredients as possible, even beyond what's listed, as you will need more of them in the second part of the quest. Altogether, you will need:

  • 25 Iron Ingot
  • 10 Red Falling Penstemon
  • 15 Green Rising Penstemon
  • 5 Sunflower
  • 25 Rope
  • 5 White & Red Hydrangea
  • 5 Purple Hydrangea
  • 5 Yellow Daisy

You can get all of the above ingredients for the first part of the Dreamlight Parks Fest: Decorate Quest as follows:

Iron Ingot

To get Iron Ingot in Disney Dreamlight Valley , you'll need to craft it using Iron Ore and Coal. You can get Coal from mining most rocks throughout the Valley, but Iron Ore is not quite as common. You can find Iron Ore by mining rock formations in the Glade of Trust, Forest of Valor, Sunlit Plateau, Forgotten Lands, or Frosted Heights biomes. There are approximately five rocks in each area where Iron Ore spawns from mining them. Therefore, the quickest way to get Iron Ore is by repeatedly mining the rocks in these areas.

You need a lot of Iron Ore to craft the 25 Iron Ingots on Scrooge's list, as you need 5 Iron Ore and 1 Coal to make a single Iron Ingot. Keep mining these rocks until you have enough for 25 Iron Ingots.

Red Falling Pestemon

Red Falling Penstemon is a Disney Dreamlight Valle y flower that you can spot by its drooping red buds. It's only possible to find Red Falling Pestemon growing in the Plaza. Gather 10 to tick this objective off Scrooge's crafting list.

Green Rising Penstemon

Disney Dreamlight Valley 's Green Rising Penstemon is perhaps the trickiest flower to find on the list, as it doesn't spawn often and its green design makes it camouflage easily into grass and other plants. You can also only gather them from the Peaceful Meadow, and you need to pick 15 of them altogether.

To get Green Rising Penstemon faster, it's best to pick them as soon as you spot them, since they take a while to respawn. The key is to keep checking back for them, as they tend to re-appear around every hour. It can also be helpful to harvest any remaining Penstemon varieties in the biome, so the game is more likely to re-spawn them.

Related
Disney Dreamlight Valley: How To Complete The Monochrome Mystery Quest

The Monochrome Mystery is an exciting quest for Merlin in Disney Dreamlight Valley. Here’s how you can complete it.

Sunflower

To get Sunflowers in Disney Dreamlight Valley , head to Dazzle Beach, the only biome where they spawn. You can usually find around four Sunflowers at any one time, but they can take a while to respawn, like other flowers in the game. While you only need five Sunflowers for the first part of the Decorate quest, you'll need a few more for the second part, so it's best to grab a few extras.

Rope

You can make Rope by first crafting Disney Dreamlight Valley 's Fiber , which requires Seaweed. You can get Green Seaweed from Dazzle Beach, and sometimes Red Seaweed from fishing in most ponds across the Valley. You can also use Red Seaweed to craft Green Seaweed if necessary.

White & Red Hydrangea

You can get White and Red Hydrangea from Dazzle Beach. Be careful though, as it looks very similar to Pink Hydrangea.

Purple Hydrangea

Purple Hydrangea is another of Disney Dreamlight Valley 's Hydrangea flowers that also grows at Dazzle Beach. However, you may need to keep checking back for it to respawn.

Yellow Daisy

Lastly, you can grab Yellow Daisies from the Peaceful Meadow. They are also a relatively common spawn, so they shouldn't be too tricky to locate.

Related
Disney Dreamlight Valley: All Eternity Isle Flowers and Where to Find Them

The magical world of Eternity Isle houses many gorgeous flowers. Here’s where players can find each of them.

How To Craft Disney Park Balloons And Colorful Park Benches

For the second part of the Dreamlight Parks: Decorate Quest, you must decorate the Valley with Dreamlight Parks Fest decorations. After gathering all of Scrooge's previous ingredients, speak to him again. He asks you to craft 5 Colorful Park Benches and 10 Disney Park Balloons . You can complete this part quickly if you previously gathered more ingredients than you needed for the first part.

Colorful Park Bench

The crafting ingredients to make a Colorful Park Bench are:

  • 5 Iron Ingot
  • 3 Green Rising Pestemon
  • 2 Red Falling Pestemon
  • 1 Sunflower

You need to craft 5 Colorful Park Benches altogether to complete this objective.

Disney Park Balloons

Make Disney Park Balloons using the following crafting ingredients:

  • 5 Rope
  • 1 White and Red Hydrangea
  • 1 Purple Hydrangea
  • 1 Yellow Daisy

Craft 5 Disney Park Balloons to complete this part of the quest.

After crafting the necessary items, decorate the Valley as you wish with the Disney Park Balloons and Colorful Park benches from your Furniture menu to complete the final part of the quest. You can place these anywhere you like outdoors, but you must use them all to complete the quest.

After decorating, return to Scrooge McDuck to receive 50 of Disney Dreamlight Valley' s green buttons as a reward . If you wish, you can now start the next Scrooge Dreamlight Parks Decorate quest, aptly named 'Decorate More.'

item.title: Dragon Age: Dreadwolf and Mass Effect 4's Romance Options Could Have a Symbiotic Relationship
item.description:
Highlights

  • Romance mechanics are crucial in Dragon Age: Dreadwolf, shaping the narrative and future of BioWare's games.
  • BioWare raised the bar for video game love stories, paving the way for deeper, more complex relationships in RPGs.
  • Dreadwolf has the opportunity to innovate through offering fresh and morally ambiguous romance options that help develop Mass Effect 4's own romance system.

Romance mechanics are likely to continue to play a major role in the upcoming Dragon Age: Dreadwolf, given the impact they have had on not only the franchise, but much of BioWare’s catalog as a whole. Choosing to find love within a distinct cast is an experience most prominently shared between DA and Mass Effect , a series with its own new game in production which will undoubtedly be affected by how Dragon Age: Dreadwolf pans out first. As more popular BioWare romances are almost certain to appear in Dreadwolf , they could set the tone for the next ME and beyond.

Passion between the player character and their companions or NPCs can be found within the likes of KOTOR 's romance , but Mass Effect elevated love and connection in BioWare titles to a cinematic level, which then made it a greater part of the studio’s identity. Despite being set within two vastly different settings, both Dragon Age: Origins and the original ME were able to find success through these personal arcs and their inherent replayability. Strong writing is at the heart of the studio’s most well-received romances, but others have received criticism for shortcomings like having predictable and archetypal natures which Dreadwolf has a chance to subvert.

Related
Dragon Age: Dreadwolf's Rumored Combat Shift May Signal a Coming Break in BioWare Tradition

The alleged change to combat that Dragon Age: Dreadwolf is set to receive has divided some fans, but standing by it could be BioWare's best bet.

BioWare Can Take Inspiration from the Strongest Elements of Romances in Past Titles

Dreadwolf Can Look to the Risk-Taking of Inquisition and Mass Effect 3

Some fairly edgy characters were romanceable in games prior to Inquisition , but the complexity in navigating the morality of certain options took this much further. Deciding the fates of Blackwall or Iron Bull as their lover has deep implications on their respective lives, for example, but Solas’ secret identity as an ancient god seeking to trigger an apocalypse who breaks the player’s heart with this reveal is on a whole other level of relevance to the greater world. More personal stakes can work just as well, but not including similarly morally ambiguous characters could be a missed opportunity.

One of ME3 ’s biggest strengths in terms of its relationships was the weight they had after the build-up of the previous games, and this is something that’s almost impossible for Dreadwolf to replicate. Even if it includes familiar faces with romantic histories, what seems to be a new player character after a considerable hiatus since Inquisition is bound to defuse tension. Tying love interests into major plot events affecting the world could evoke some of the gravity that Mass Effect 3 ’s most dire consequences are capable of, but this might be an aspect of DA that needs to build over time in the same way.

Cross-Influence in Romance Between Dragon Age: Dreadwolf and Mass Effect 4 Would Be a Boon

Borrowing the Most Successful Elements from Mass Effect and Dragon Age

Assuming that Dreadwolf manages to achieve the same narrative quality as its predecessor in terms of how its love interests are written, its lasting success would open up the chance to develop that same cast in further installments which bring the player closer to them. If the stakes of Inquisition can come together with the slow-burn benefits of Mass Effect , Dreadwolf could shine as a story-driven experience no matter the format of its combat. This could even subsequently pave the way for more romance options who rival the depth and importance of Solas in the next ME to create a strong foundation for future titles that iterate even further.

Staggered BioWare Development Cycles Can Better Utilize Player Feedback

Possible release windows suggest that the next Dragon Age will be arriving before Mass Effect 4 , and this will create the opportunity for romances in the latter to be refined based on how they are received in the studio’s next big outing. Some players have found the multitude of edgy dark-haired women and similarly attractive men with light hair throughout DA to be repetitive. Addressing this kind of reception would be the best way to ensure that future BioWare RPGs can feature intimate relationships that innovate and grow with each installment.

item.title: Pokemon Scarlet & Violet: Iron Thorns & Sandy Shocks 5-Star Tera Raid Guide
item.description:
Pokemon Scarlet & Violet is giving players a chance to take on Iron Thorns & Sandy Shocks as part of its latest Tera raid event. The Iron Thorns & Sandy Shocks Tera Raid event is a 5-star event, and players will be getting a plethora of rewards for that.

While this is a 5-star Tera Raid and significantly easier than the 7-Star Tera raids which take place in Pokemon Scarlet & Violet from time to time, the aspect that makes it much harder is the fact that it will be of random Tera-types. Now, considering the impact Tera-types have on the entire dynamics of the battle, it becomes extremely difficult to plan for this.

For those who aren't unaware, Tera-type adds a new type to the same-type-attack-bonus, or simply multiplies the bonus even further if the Tera-type is the same. Not to forget, the weaknesses are totally replaced by that of the new Tera-type. Thus, knowing Iron Thorns or Sandy Shocks isn't that useful considering the fact that it will most likely be replaced.

Related
Pokemon Scarlet & Violet: All Gyms, Ranked By Difficulty

For players wondering which gym to try first, check out this list of which is the easiest and hardest gym to take on.

How To Unlock 5-Star Raids In Pokemon Scarlet & Violet

Unlike 7-Star Tera Raid, 5-Star Tera Raids are much easier to unlock in the game and players shouldn't have much trouble with them. Precisely, players will need to complete the game first , meaning players will have to wrap up all three paths; Victory Road, Path of Legends, and Starfall Street. Once that's done, the Academy Ace Tournament also needs to be completed, which can be slightly tricky without the right team. With all that completed, players will then be able to unlock 5-star Tera raids. When applicable, they will get a call from Professor Jacq which will notify them that 5-star Tera Raids are now available.

Best Counter & Weakness For Iron Thorns & Sandy Shocks

Despite the difficulties surrounding the strategies for the battle, players can still have a good selection of well-rounded Pokemon to ensure that they can counter any type that comes up during the battle. There are three Pokemon that are considered the absolute best in this department, which is Annihilape, Azumarill, and Iron Hands . Annihilapee is considered as the go-to choice by the community, but the other two are not that far behind.

As per the current meta, players should be using a very specific build for Annihilape to make the most out of it. That is, with the Ghost Tera-type , and with an adamant nature that boosts its Attack at the cost of Special Attack . The best ability is Defiant, which further boosts its attack when subject to stat changes. A very crucial item to have for this build is the Shell Bell , which helps the Annihilape to restore HP. For the moveset, the preferred ones are Rage Fist, Drain Punch, Bulk Up, and Screech.

The strategy for this fight is quite simple, as players should always start with Bulk Up. Then Screech is going to make it easier to reduce the opponent's HP, while Drain Punch can be used to restore HP whenever required. And once the terrestallization opens up, players can simply spam Rage Fist, which should be enough to wrap up the battle.
